repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
This b is determined to be true by tbl_islist, but since it is not sequentially numbered, ipairs will not work.
```lua
local b = { 'foo', 'bar', 'baz' }
b[1] = nil
for i, v in ipairs(b) do
  print('b:ipairs', i, v)
end
```

comment_data.body: better move the definition to the doc text above, and leave `list-like table` here
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -401,24 +401,28 @@ end
 --- for example from |rpcrequest()| or |vim.fn|.
 ---
 ---@param t Table
----@returns `true` if array-like table, else `false`.
+---@return boolean @`true` if list (table indexed with sequential integers starting from 1), else `false`.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- Tests if a Lua table can be treated as an array (a table indexed by integers).
---
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -396,13 +396,16 @@ end
 
 --- Tests if a Lua table can be treated as an array.
 ---
+--- `Array` is a indexing table with integers.
+--- `List` is a table indexed with sequential integers starting from 1.
+---

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- Tests if a Lua table can be treated as a list (a table indexed by consecutive integers starting from 1).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -429,6 +432,48 @@ function vim.tbl_islist(t)
   end
 end
 
+--- Tests if a Lua table can be treated as a list.
+---
+--- `Array` is a indexing table with integers.
+--- `List` is a table indexed with sequential integers starting from 1.

comment_data.body: @clason @bfredl  Should I still keep this TODO?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -548,6 +548,45 @@ function vim.tbl_islist(t)
   end
 end
 
+--- Tests if a Lua table can be treated as a list (a table indexed by consecutive integers starting from 1).
+---
+--- Empty table `{}` is assumed to be an list, unless it was created by
+--- |vim.empty_dict()| or returned as a dict-like |API| or Vimscript result,
+--- for example from |rpcrequest()| or |vim.fn|.
+---
+---@param t table
+---@return boolean `true` if list-like table, else `false`.
+function vim.tbl_islist(t)
+  if type(t) ~= 'table' then
+    return false
+  end
+
+  local count = 0
+  local max_idx = 0
+
+  for k, _ in pairs(t) do
+    if type(k) == 'number' and k > 0 then
+      count = count + 1
+      if max_idx < k then
+        max_idx = k
+      end
+    else
+      return false
+    end
+  end
+
+  if count > 0 then
+    return count == max_idx
+  else
+    -- TODO(bfredl): in the future, we will always be inside nvim
+    -- then this check can be deleted.
+    if vim._empty_dict_mt == nil then
+      return nil
+    end

comment_data.body: That's right, I was meaning to ask @bfredl whether we are already in the future now!
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -548,6 +548,45 @@ function vim.tbl_islist(t)
   end
 end
 
+--- Tests if a Lua table can be treated as a list (a table indexed by consecutive integers starting from 1).
+---
+--- Empty table `{}` is assumed to be an list, unless it was created by
+--- |vim.empty_dict()| or returned as a dict-like |API| or Vimscript result,
+--- for example from |rpcrequest()| or |vim.fn|.
+---
+---@param t table
+---@return boolean `true` if list-like table, else `false`.
+function vim.tbl_islist(t)
+  if type(t) ~= 'table' then
+    return false
+  end
+
+  local count = 0
+  local max_idx = 0
+
+  for k, _ in pairs(t) do
+    if type(k) == 'number' and k > 0 then
+      count = count + 1
+      if max_idx < k then
+        max_idx = k
+      end
+    else
+      return false
+    end
+  end
+
+  if count > 0 then
+    return count == max_idx
+  else
+    -- TODO(bfredl): in the future, we will always be inside nvim
+    -- then this check can be deleted.
+    if vim._empty_dict_mt == nil then
+      return nil
+    end

comment_data.body:
I don't think that's a valid array (not indexed by integers), so this should return `false`.

What does openResty/luaJIT2 `table.isarray()` return for that?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -505,6 +505,19 @@ describe('lua stdlib', function()
     ]]))
   end)
 
+  it('vim.tbl_isarray', function()
+    eq(true, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({})"))
+    eq(false, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray(vim.empty_dict())"))
+    eq(true, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({'a', 'b', 'c'})"))
+    eq(false, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({'a', '32', a='hello', b='baz'})"))
+    eq(false, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({1, a='hello', b='baz'})"))
+    eq(false, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({a='hello', b='baz', 1})"))
+    eq(false, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({1, 2, nil, a='hello'})"))
+    eq(true, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({1, 2, nil, 4})"))
+    eq(true, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({nil, 2, 3, 4})"))
+    eq(true, exec_lua("return vim.tbl_isarray({1, [1.5]=2, [3]=3})"))

comment_data.body: I have checked the definition. As you say, it is indeed only integers.

comment_data.body:
I would also fix tbl_isarray, since it only looks at whether it is a number or not.
There are several ways to determine if it is an integer, is there a standard method used by neovim?

comment_data.body: I haven't heard back, so I'll leave this one for now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -548,6 +548,45 @@ function vim.tbl_islist(t)
   end
 end
 
+--- Tests if a Lua table can be treated as a list (a table indexed by consecutive integers starting from 1).
+---
+--- Empty table `{}` is assumed to be an list, unless it was created by
+--- |vim.empty_dict()| or returned as a dict-like |API| or Vimscript result,
+--- for example from |rpcrequest()| or |vim.fn|.
+---
+---@param t table
+---@return boolean `true` if list-like table, else `false`.
+function vim.tbl_islist(t)
+  if type(t) ~= 'table' then
+    return false
+  end
+
+  local count = 0
+  local max_idx = 0
+
+  for k, _ in pairs(t) do
+    if type(k) == 'number' and k > 0 then
+      count = count + 1
+      if max_idx < k then
+        max_idx = k
+      end
+    else
+      return false
+    end
+  end
+
+  if count > 0 then
+    return count == max_idx
+  else
+    -- TODO(bfredl): in the future, we will always be inside nvim
+    -- then this check can be deleted.
+    if vim._empty_dict_mt == nil then
+      return nil
+    end

comment_regular_data.body:
After a bit of thinking, I am in favor of this. While `tbl_islist` is not (and should not) be used as a guard for `ipairs` in our code, arguably that is how you would expect a list to behave.

In addition, this also distinguishes it from OpenResty's [`table.isarray`](https://github.com/openresty/luajit2#tableisarray), which does not care about holes (correctly in my view, since "sparse arrays" are a thing both in Lua and in practice).

I think the fact that this throws an error is also a criterion for whether it is an "array" or not.
```lua
vim.g.hoge = { [2] = "b", [3] = "c" }
```
`E5100: Cannot convert given lua table: table should either have a sequence of positive integer keys or contain only string keys`

`array` != `list`, and I think we should be consistent in the terminology (I _hate_ that the documentation for `tbl_islist` only talks about "arrays" -- why is it not called `isarray` then?)

(The error message can be made even more explicit, of course, although it should be obvious what is meant here.)

On a related note, please add a definition of list to the docstring (table indexed with sequential integers starting from 1).

Note that in Lua, an [array is simply an integer-indexed table](https://www.lua.org/pil/11.1.html); in particular, it can start at _any_ index!
Should the tbl_islist in line 242 (in can_merge) be tbl_isarray?

> Should the tbl_islist in line 242 (in can_merge) be tbl_isarray?

I'd say test it with an array that is not a list (starts from 2 or has holes), and if it works, change it to `tbl_isarray`.
If we go down that route, we should also check the other occurrences of `tbl_islist` in the codebase (lsp, `_meta.lua`, and especially the tests).
Documentation is auto-generated, don't (need to) change `lua.txt`. (But wait for the checks to finish before pushing again; this'll give us a first idea what tests need to be adapted.)
This PR may need a better commit message. Maybe `feat(lua)!: add stricter vim.tbl_islist() and rename old one to vim.tbl_isarray()`.

This pull request has been mentioned on **Neovim Discourse**. There might be relevant details there:

https://neovim.discourse.group/t/confusion-between-array-and-list/1485/2

Just a small note that I have not forgotten about this and would like to merge this now that 0.9 is released; it just lead me down a rabbit hole of `vim.tbl_` vs. `vim.list_` inconsistencies that I'd like to have a plan for first...
What about naming it something like `vim.list_validate()` or `vim.list_assert()`?
No, `isfoo()` is the standard idiom here, and it would be better to stick with it (for openResty compatibility, for example).

Ok.
How about making it `vim.islist()` or even better, `vim.type` module?
No, let's keep the names as they are.

Hmm, I misunderstood. Sorry.
I thought you were saying that vim.tbl_* expects a map-like table, so it is strange that it is followed by islist.

Sorry, that was unclear. `vim.tbl_` should apply to _any_  table, while `vim.list_` should _only_ apply to list-like tables. (There's no need for `vim.array_` functions as I don't expect these to be very useful in practice; we're keeping the old function mostly for compatibility.)

Needs
* [x] rebase
* [x] fixing lint errors (`stylua runtime` from repo root)
* [x] generate docs
* [x] news.txt entry (under "Breaking changes")
* [x] test in  `test/functional/lua/vim_spec.lua` (start by copying the test in line 508ff, then add a test case for a non-list array to each)

Then it's good to go! :)
@uga-rosa I took the liberty of addressing my own todo notes and force-pushing to your PR -- I hope that's OK!

I think it's a legitimate request and correction. Thank you.

I believe the islist algorithm needs to be corrected, so please wait for the merge yet. It is not judging correctly when a decimal number is the key.
I've fixed the algorithm and added tests.
Thank you for your patience and for seeing this through!
I really start to think that every feature or function added should be marked with a version in which it first appears. It would be easy to write cross-runtime lua-code.
`:h news.txt`
@max397574 Nope. It's only for newly added features between two last and new verisons. It doesn't keep track of features added in old versions.

title: feat(lua)!: add stricter vim.tbl_islist() and rename old one to vim.tbl_isarray()
